title: Pyogenic Liver Abscess
diagnosis_topic: Infection of hepatic parenchyma resulting in abscess formation
setup_script: A 55-year-old man with a history of diabetes presents with fever, chills and right upper quadrant pain for one week. He denies jaundice.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 120/75 mmHg, HR 102 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 38.7 C.
Tender hepatomegaly in right upper quadrant; no Murphy's sign.
WBC 20 K/uL, alkaline phosphatase elevated, transaminases mildly elevated; blood cultures pending.
Ultrasound shows 5 cm hypoechoic lesion in right lobe; CT confirms multiloculated abscess.
Empiric coverage for enteric Gram-negatives and anaerobes (ceftriaxone plus metronidazole).
Percutaneous drainage catheter placed; pus culture guides antibiotics.
May treat with antibiotics alone but close monitoring needed.
Abscess may rupture causing peritonitis and sepsis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for underlying source
dynamic_flow.reply: Search for biliary obstruction, portal vein bacteremia from diverticulitis or appendicitis.
Repeat ultrasound to ensure resolution after 2 weeks.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident outlines duration of antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Typically 4-6 weeks depending on culture results and clinical response.
Emphasize completing antibiotic course and monitoring for recurrent symptoms.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of liver abscess via imaging and clinical suspicion
Indications for percutaneous drainage versus antibiotics alone
Evaluation for underlying source of infection
Monitoring treatment response with imaging and prolonged antibiotics
